Introduction

Cholera is a potentially life-threatening gastrointestinal infection caused by Vibrio cholerae serogroups O1 and O139.  Three million cases of cholera occur each year worldwide, resulting in around 100,000 deaths.  Severe disease is marked by profuse watery diarrhea, which can lead to life-threatening dehydration, hypovolemic shock, and electrolyte disturbances.  Cholera is commonly seen in areas with inadequate sanitation, making it a significant public health issue in low-income and disaster-stricken regions.

Microbiology and pathophysiology



V cholerae is a comma-shaped, oxidase-positive, highly motile, gram-negative rod that is transmitted via the fecal-oral route and through contaminated food (eg, seafood) and water.



After ingestion, V cholerae passes through the acidic stomach, colonizes (but does not invade) the small intestine epithelium, and releases cholera toxin.  Cholera toxin is an exotoxin that binds to epithelial receptors, triggering a cascade of intracellular events that ultimately lead to the activation of adenylate cyclase and an increase in cyclic AMP (cAMP).  Elevated cAMP levels disrupt normal ion transport, resulting in excessive secretion of chloride ions and inhibition of sodium absorption.  This osmotic imbalance leads to massive fluid and electrolyte efflux into the intestinal lumen, causing the characteristic profuse, watery diarrhea.

Pathology



Pathologic findings in cholera are primarily confined to the small intestine.  Histological examination reveals minimal mucosal inflammation or damage because cholera toxin's action is limited to the epithelium's secretory mechanisms rather than inducing cellular injury.  V cholerae does not invade tissue, and systemic spread is rare.

Risk factors



Risk factors for disease transmission and more severe disease include the following:



  • Geography:  Living in an endemic area (eg, southern Asia, Sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America), especially during seasonal outbreaks (typically prior to and after rainy seasons).
  • Inadequate sanitation:  Lack of clean water and adequate sewage disposal.
  • Patient characteristics:  Blood group O (associated with more severe disease, possibly related to cholera toxin–induced hyperactivation), malnutrition, and reduced gastric acidity (eg, partial gastrectomy, which promotes pathogen survival).

Clinical presentation



V cholerae infection ranges from asymptomatic colonization to life-threatening diarrhea.  However, most infections are asymptomatic or cause only mild symptoms.



When symptomatic, patients typically present with watery diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping, which occur after an incubation period of 1-2 days.  Because the infection is not invasive, fever and bloody diarrhea are typically not present; significant abdominal pain is also not present.  Mild infections typically self-resolve within a week.



In 5%-10% of cases, diarrhea becomes severe (eg, 1 L of stool per hour) and can result in death within hours due to dehydration and electrolyte imbalance if not treated promptly.  The stool is often described as "rice water diarrhea," containing gray and cloudy liquid stool with flecks of mucus.  Patients also present with signs of severe dehydration, including sunken eyes, decreased skin turgor, tachycardia, lethargy, and hypotension.

Diagnosis



Diagnosis of cholera is generally made presumptively based on the presence of acute, watery diarrhea that accompanies severe dehydration, especially when present in areas with active outbreaks.  In areas without outbreaks, it may also be suspected in those who have symptoms of cholera and have eaten poorly cooked shellfish.



Given that distinguishing cholera from other infectious causes of watery diarrhea is impossible, stool culture using a special media (thiosulfate citrate bile sucrose agar or taurocholate tellurite gelatin agar) can be used to confirm the diagnosis.  In settings where immediate diagnosis is critical (eg, confirming outbreaks), rapid diagnostic tests (eg, stool dipsticks, darkfield microscopy) can be used instead of stool culture.

Evaluation



Evaluation of patients with cholera centers around assessing the degree of dehydration, which guides subsequent management.



Clinical features of dehydration and the estimated fluid loss are discussed below.

No significant dehydration



  • No significant dehydration (fluid loss <5% body weight) is associated with no abnormalities on examination (eg, well and alert, no sunken eyes, not thirsty, normal skin turgor).  Fluid deficit is <50 mL/kg body weight.

Moderate dehydration



  • Moderate dehydration (fluid loss 5%-10% body weight) presents with ≥2 of the following: restlessness, sunken eyes, thirst, and reduced skin turgor.  Fluid deficit is 50-100 mL/kg body weight.

Severe dehydration



  • Severe dehydration (fluid loss >10% body weight):  Presents with ≥2 of lethargy, inability to drink fluids, severely reduced skin turgor (≥2 seconds to recoil), or sunken eyes; in addition, tachycardia, weak pulse, and hypotension are also present.  Fluid deficit is >100 mL/kg body weight.


A basic metabolic panel to check electrolyte status and renal function is often unnecessary when no significant dehydration or moderate dehydration is present.  However, it is recommended for those with severe dehydration as intravenous fluid and electrolyte supplementations generally become necessary.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of cholera includes other causes of acute watery diarrhea.  However, differentiating among these infections based on clinical presentation alone without stool studies is difficult.



  • Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli:  Causes watery diarrhea through toxin-mediated mechanisms.  It typically affects low-resource areas or travelers to these areas who have consumed contaminated food or water.  It typically affects older children and adults, and patients generally do not experience vomiting.
  • Rotavirus and norovirus:  Common viral causes of gastroenteritis that present with watery diarrhea, especially in children.  These infections are often associated with fever and vomiting.
  • Cryptosporidium:  A parasitic infection that causes watery diarrhea; it is self-limited in immunocompetent patients and has a prolonged course in the immunocompromised.
  • Shigella and salmonella:  Present with dysentery (bloody diarrhea), abdominal pain, and fever, distinguishing them from cholera (which causes watery diarrhea).

Management

Rehydration



The primary focus for management of cholera is prompt and aggressive fluid replacement to counteract dehydration.  Rehydration can be accomplished through oral rehydration solution (ORS) and/or intravenous fluid (IVF).



  • ORS contains equimolar amounts of dextrose (glucose) and sodium, which are absorbed via intestinal cotransport to maintain intravascular volume status.  ORS often contains potassium to compensate for gastrointestinal losses and citrate to buffer metabolic acidosis.  (Water alone may exacerbate electrolyte disturbances [eg, hyponatremia, hypoglycemia], and the high sorbitol content of juice can worsen diarrhea.)
  • The preferred IVF is Ringer lactate, with or without dextrose, as it contains potassium and sodium lactate, a base to buffer metabolic acidosis.  In contrast, normal saline lacks potassium and a base, and is therefore less preferred.


The type and amount of rehydration therapy used to correct dehydration depends on the severity of dehydration and tolerance of oral intake.



  • No significant dehydration:  Patients can generally tolerate oral intake; therefore, ORS is used to replace ongoing fluid losses (due to diarrhea and vomiting).
  • Moderate dehydration:  Patients can generally tolerate oral intake; therefore, ORS is used to replace fluid deficit and ongoing losses.
  • Severe dehydration:  Patients may be lethargic and unable to drink (due to lethargy or excessive vomiting); therefore, IVF is used to replace fluid deficit and ongoing losses.  ORS should be started as soon as the patient is able to tolerate oral intake.

Adjunctive measures



In addition to rehydration therapy, the following adjunctive measures should also be utilized.



  • Antibiotic therapy (eg, doxycycline, azithromycin, and ciprofloxacin):  Recommended for patients with moderate or severe dehydration based on local resistance patterns.  Antibiotics can reduce the duration and volume of diarrhea.
  • Nutritional support:  Patients with cholera should resume normal feeding as soon as possible to aid recovery and prevent malnutrition.
  • Vitamin/mineral supplementation:  Zinc and vitamin A supplementation are recommended, especially for children in resource-limited settings; these have been shown to reduce the severity and duration of diarrhea.

Prevention



Prevention of cholera involves ensuring access to clean water and adequate sanitation.  Tap water and uncooked or inadequately cooked foods should be avoided during travel to endemic regions.  In addition, vaccinations (eg, inactivated, live-attenuated) have been utilized to reduce the risk of infection.  Breastfeeding is encouraged to prevent gastrointestinal infections in infants and children.

Complications



Complications of cholera arise primarily from severe dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.



  • Hypovolemic shock:  Rapid fluid loss can lead to shock and multiorgan failure (eg, prerenal azotemia, acute tuber necrosis) if rehydration is not promptly initiated.
  • Electrolyte disturbances:  Potassium, sodium, and calcium losses through the stool can result in muscle weakness and arrhythmias.  Bicarbonate loss (and lactic acidosis that results from hypovolemic shock) can result in metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation (eg, Kussmaul breathing).
  • Malnutrition:  Prolonged diarrheal episodes can lead to malnutrition, sometimes due to chronic malabsorption.
  • Pneumonia:  Pneumonia is a significant cause of death in children with cholera, presumably caused by aspiration from vomiting.
  • Pregnancy complications:  Miscarriage, premature delivery, and stillbirth can occur in pregnant patients with cholera.

Prognosis



Most people infected with cholera are asymptomatic or develop mild, self-limited illness that resolves within a week.  However, 5%-10% of patients develop severe cholera, which can lead to death within hours if fluid and electrolyte loss are rapid; mortality can reach 70% if untreated.  With timely rehydration therapy, the prognosis of cholera is excellent with mortality rates <1%.  The prognosis worsens significantly in settings with limited access to medical care, clean water, and sanitation, as these factors contribute to both transmission and delays in life-saving medical care.

Summary



Cholera is an acute diarrheal disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae, which produces a toxin leading to rapid fluid loss and watery diarrhea.  Approximately 5%-10% of cases result in severe, potentially life-threatening dehydration within hours.  Transmission is primarily through ingestion of contaminated water or food.  Diagnosis is generally clinical in endemic settings, confirmed by stool culture if needed.  Treatment focuses on aggressive rehydration, electrolyte management, and antibiotics in more severe cases.  Preventative measures, including improved sanitation and vaccination, play a critical role in controlling outbreaks.
